page.title: 06History of open air theatre
page.content: In 1964, the quarter centenary of Shakespeare's birth, 2 members of the Bournemouth Little Theatre Club, decided that something should be done to celebrate this event. They chose to perform Shakespeare's "The Tempest" on Brownsea Island because of it's enchanting scenery and novel venue. The council at first refused but following a number of meetings consented. The National Trust agreed to sponsor the event. The play was put on for 3 nights, but owing to public demand was extended for another night. The old cowshed was found to have an electricity supply and so it was decided that the ploughed field behind the cowshed should be used as the acting area. Following the success of this first production, performances of a play have become an annual event on the island.
